Introduction

1.1. This policy ensures that staff have the right to appeal against formal action taken against them, in accordance with Trust policies, that they believe are not (or have not been) arrived at in a fair, reasonable and consistent way. An appeal is a request to review the decision, action or procedure. It is not a re- hearing.
1.2. The aims of this policy are to:
Ensure  that  the  Trust  is  a  fair  employer,  meeting  all  relevant  legal requirements  regarding  any  formal  action,  dismissal  or  relegation decisions it may take in relation to staff;
Ensure that lawful, non-discriminatory and effective arrangements are in place for dealing with appeal hearings;
Ensure  that  all  members  of  staff  are  treated  in  a  fair  and  consistent manner.
Scope
2.1. This policy covers all staff who are employed by the Trust.

2.2. For Medical and Dental staff, this policy should be read in conjunction with the Department of health's Maintaining High Professional Standards document, which provides clear guidance as to additional steps to be taken when managing an appeal from a medical member of staff, particularly in the case of an appeal against termination of contract.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
The Appellant refers to the member of staff and their representative (a Trade Union/Professional Body representative or workplace colleague).
The Respondent refers to the Presenting Manager.
The appeal panel is responsible for ensuring the appeal hearing is held in accordance with this policy, including adherence to
timescales. They are also responsible for agreeing amendments to the timescales where required.

data.text: Purpose

4.1. A member of staff will have the right of appeal against any formal decision or action  taken  against  them  under  Trust  policy  (i.e.  Disciplinary,  Bullying  & Harassment) or any other dismissal or sanction.
4.2. Appeals may be raised by a member of staff on the following grounds only:
New evidence that has come to light since the hearing;
Undue severity of the decision;
Inconsistency of the penalty contrary to precedent;
A defect in the procedure or process.
Duties & Responsibilities
Member of staff/Appellants

5.1. Should a member of staff wish to appeal against a management decision that has been made against them, staff as appellants are responsible for ensuring they comply with the requirements of this policy at all times and behave in a professional and appropriate manner during all meetings or hearings to discuss their appeal.
5.2. Should staff wish the right to be accompanied by a Trade Union representative or work colleague at an appeal hearing, they will be responsible for arranging this for themselves.

5.3. In order to submit an appeal the member of staff should complete the appeal form (appendix 2) and send to the Head of Employee Relations which should clearly state their grounds of appeal based on Section  of this policy. If this does not occur the appeal may be delayed or rejected.
Manager/Respondent
5.4. The manager who made the decision being appealed is responsible for providing a response to the employees appeal form. This should be submitted to the chair of the panel within 7 calendar days.
5.5. The respondent must adhere to the principles set out in this policy and fully participate in the process.
The Appeal Panel
5.6. An appeal panel will be convened to consider any appeals received by the Trust in accordance with this policy.

5.7. The appeal panel is responsible for ensuring the appeal hearing is held in accordance with this policy, including adherence to timescales. They are also responsible for agreeing amendments to the timescales where required.
5.8. The appeal panel is also responsible for ensuring the appeal hearing and any decision made is fair and equitable.
The Employee Relations Team
5.9. The Employee Relations Team will be responsible for advising and supporting all parties on the operation of this procedure and for providing specific management and staff guidance.
5.10. Ensure that clear grounds of appeal have been received by the Trust.
5.11. The Panel will be supported by a member of the Employee Relations Team who is responsible for advising the Appeals Panel on procedure.
Appeal Panel Members
6.1. Panel members must consider grounds for appeal fairly during the hearing and come to a fair and justifiable decision as to the outcome of the appeal hearing.
6.2. The Chair of the Panel must write to confirm the outcome of the hearing to the appellant and responding manager within 7 calendar days of the date of the
hearing.
6.3. The members of the Appeal Panel shall not include any members of the Trust who have been involved either in the circumstances leading to the original Hearing or have sat on the original Panel.
6.4. Managers who have been involved at earlier stage of the formal hearing process will only be present in the capacity as a witness at the Appeal Hearing.
Levels of Appeal
Appeals against dismissal will be heard by a Panel chaired by an Associate Director Senior Manager of higher status than the dismissing manager.
Appeals against any other outcome or sanction will be heard by a Panel chaired by a Manager of higher status than the original Chair of the decision making panel.
Powers of the Appeal Panel

8.1. The Appeal panel has the right to call witnesses where considered relevant and appropriate; however all parties must be notified at least seven calendar days in advance of the hearing. Exceptionally, where during the course of the hearing the Appeal Panel determines that they need to hear the evidence of a witness not called by either party, they will have the power to adjourn the hearing accordingly.

8.2. If, during the course of the hearing the Appeal Panel determines that new evidence needs to be presented, they will consider whether an adjournment is appropriate: much will depend on the weight of the new evidence and its relevance. The appeal panel has the power to determine whether to consider the new evidence as relevant to the appeal, or whether the case should be reheard on the basis of the new evidence by an independent panel in accordance with the relevant policy.
Witnesses
9.1. It is the responsibility of each side to arrange the attendance of any required witnesses.
9.2. Members of staff who are asked to attend appeal hearings as witnesses will be allowed time off to attend without loss of pay.

9.3. It will be the responsibility of each witness to inform their manager for time off to attend an appeal hearing. Once notified by the witness, the manager should ensure that time off is provided to attend the appeal hearing.
9.4. Where possible, witnesses for the respective parties must wait in separate rooms and must not be present throughout the Appeal Hearing except for the purpose of giving evidence.
9.5. Witnesses do not have the right to be made aware of the outcome of the Appeal Hearing they are attending due to confidentiality.
Timelines
10.1. If formal proceedings are commenced by a manager against a member of staff, then a provisional date for appeal hearing should be diarised for the appeal hearing.

10.2. If the member of staff wishes to appeal, they must do so by submitting the appeal form (appendix 2) to the Head of Employee Relations or next level of management if appropriate, within  calendar days of receipt of written notification of an outcome decision.
10.3. An appeal will be heard within 21 calendar days from receipt of the appeal.
10.4. The member of staff will be provided with the written outcome of the appeal by the Appeal Panel, within 7 calendar days from the Trust Appeal Panel Hearing date.
Right to Representation
Staff who lodge an appeal have the right to be represented at the appeal by their trade union representative. Alternatively they may wish to be accompanied by a work place colleague.
Appeal Outcome
The decision reached by the Appeal Panel will be the final outcome and the member of staff will have exhausted the Trust process.
Guidance Relating to Appeal Hearings
Introduction to appeal hearings
13.1. The Hearing will normally comprise of a Panel (the Appeal Panel) comprising of:
13.2. Appeals against dismissal will be heard by a Panel chaired by the Associate Director of the relevant Division.

13.3. Appeals against any other outcome or sanction will be heard by a Panel chaired by a Manager of higher status than the original Chair of the decision making panel supported by a senior member of the Employee Relations Team.

13.4. Appeals  against  sanctions  placed  by  professionally  registered  staff,  a  senior manager of the same profession will also be on the Panel together with the senior member of the Employee Relations Team.

13.5. The primary role of the Employee Relations panel member is to advise and share their specialist knowledge of procedural issues, relevant Trust policies and employment law matters. They will participate fully in any discussions about the case.
13.6. The Panel may at its discretion adjourn the hearing at any time in order that further evidence may be produced by either party.

13.7. Both parties are entitled to call witnesses to support their case (see Appeal Procedure for details). Witnesses will only be in attendance when they are giving evidence. Where possible, witnesses will be provided with a time of attendance in order to minimise disruption to service provision within the Trust. However, ‘The Panel' may request witnesses to remain available after they have given evidence, if they consider this beneficial in establishing the facts of the case.
13.8. All parties involved in the Hearing are responsible for maintaining the confidentiality of all information shared during the proceedings.
Staff Representative
14.1. The member of staff has the right to be accompanied.

14.2. There is no duty on the Trade Union/Professional Body representative to accept a request to be a member of staff's representative. No pressure should be put upon a person who chooses not to act as a representative.
14.3. The representative has the right to address the Hearing but has no right to answer questions on the member of staff's behalf.
Order of Proceedings During an Appeal Hearing
At the start of the Hearing, the Chairman of the Panel will:
15.1. Introduce everyone present.
15.2. Check that those present have received the supporting documentation in connection with the Hearing.
15.3. Indicate the grounds of which the hearing is being heard, i.e. severity of the penalty or procedure.
15.4. Indicate that the Panel is able to ask for clarification of any evidence the Appellant or the Respondent provide at any stage during the Hearing.
15.5. Explain how the Hearing will be conducted (see below).
Presentation of the Appellant's Case
16.1. The Appellant will state the grounds of their Appeal.
16.2. The Respondent will have the opportunity to ask questions of the Appellant or their representative.
16.3. The Panel will have the opportunity to ask questions of the Appellant or their representative.
16.4. The Appellant may call any witnesses. If witnesses are called, the Chairman must introduce the witness and those present at the Hearing.
16.5. The Appellant will have the opportunity to ask questions of their witnesses on any matter arising.
16.6. The Respondent will have the opportunity to ask questions of the witness.
16.7. The Panel will have the opportunity to ask questions of the witnesses.
Presentation of the Management Case
17.1. The Respondent will state their case.
17.2. The Appellant or their Representative will have the opportunity to ask questions of The Respondent.
17.3. The Panel will have the opportunity to ask questions of The Respondent.
17.4. The Respondent may call witnesses. If witnesses are called, the Chair of the Panel must introduce the witness and those present at the Hearing.
17.5. The Respondent will have the opportunity to ask questions of their witnesses on any matter arising.
17.6. The Appellant will have the opportunity to ask questions of the witnesses.
17.7. The Panel will have the opportunity to ask questions of the witnesses.
Summing Up

18.1. The Respondent and The Appellant will have the opportunity to sum up their case if they wish to do so. The Respondent will sum up their case first. Neither party may introduce any new information at this point.

18.2. The  Respondent,  The  Appellant,  their  representative  and  any  witnesses  still present will withdraw, so that The Panel can deliberate in private. The Panel may recall both parties to clarify any points of uncertainty on evidence already given. If a recall is necessary both parties will return, even if only one is concerned with the point in question.
Outcome of the Hearing
19.1. The Respondent, The Appellant and their representative will be called to return to the meeting room.
19.2. The  Chair  of  the  Panel  will  communicate  the  decision  and  will  send  written confirmation within 7 calendar days.
The Panel will determine whether:
19.3. To uphold the whole appeal.
19.4. To uphold part of the appeal; (for example, a disciplinary sanction could then be of a lesser penalty).
19.5. To reject the appeal and dismiss the case.

19.6. The member of staff whose appeal against dismissal is successful will normally be reinstated in their previous position. In certain circumstances, e.g., if the previous working relationship appears to have broken down, it may be more appropriate for the member of staff to be reinstated in a different position or Division  of  comparable  status  and  pay.  This  will  take  place  only  after  full discussion and agreement with the member of staff, their representative and the relevant Line Managers. In all cases there will be no loss of continuity of service or associated rights. If the member of staff notice has already expired, and they have left the Trust's employment, they will receive the appropriate amount of back pay for the period between the effective date of termination of employment and the date of reinstatement.

19.7. A member of staff whose appeal against relegation is successful will similarly be reinstated. If their pay has been reduced as part of the relegation decision, the difference will be made up so that no financial loss is incurred.
Training Requirements
20.1.  This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
Monitoring and Audit

24.2. In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was found to be compliant with this assessment. (Refer to Appendix 1)
